messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> Proper spelling is
> engrained in most people today, but I believe that in Elizabethan
> times the concept of a "correct" spelling was either non-existent or
> much weaker.

Weaker, certainly. Shakespeare's name was spelled in many strange
ways by his contemporaries ("Shagsper" being my favorite), but
professional scribes and printers almost always spelled it the same way.
See <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spelling_of_William_Shakespeare's_name>.

> I would argue that if it is clear what word you are
> intending to represent, a slightly different spelling from an
> arbitrary "standard" should cause no difficulty in reading.

Studies show that an unexpected misspelling does in fact slow down
reading, even tho [sic] it may itself represent an improovement [sic].

> Another point is that English seems peculiarly resistant to modification
> of standardized spelling over time when pronunciation has changed as
> compared to other languages such as German or Spanish.

True enough. It took ten years for four countries to reform German
spelling in 1996, and there is still plenty of resistance. English
is official in at least fifty countries, and it would probably take
a hundred years for a similar modest reform effort to bear fruit.

> I have not gone back and checked the group messages from the past,
> but I remember long detailed discussions about how necessary
> standardizing QS spelling was. The people pushing this idea seem
> much more focused on this than seems necessary to me, and they
> seemed very adamant about it.

The issue arises when Alice, who distinguishes between the Ox, Ah, and
Awe sounds, is trying to read QS written by Bob, who doesn't. It would
be like trying to figure out what someone means by "There's a lot of
feft in my area" when you have never heard of Estuary English.

> The idea of the existence of "silent" letters brings this out. A
> couple of years ago I learned of an elementary teacher who was telling
> her young students that the "h" in words such as "which" and "why" was
> a silent letter. Presumably, for her it was, but I suspect she had no
> idea that many people still pronounce it and consider it important.

Relatively few people in fact still distinguish between "whine" and "wine".
Outside Scotland, Ireland, and parts of the American South, this merger has
gone to completion, though people who do not have the merger often believe
that they hear it in other people's speech even when it isn't there.

By the same token, it's not quite correct to say that "meet" and "meat"
sound the same, for in a few regions of England they are still distinct.
But for almost everyone else it's a distinction without a difference.

> No wonder it is a dying sound with that lack of knowledge on the part
> of the people teaching our children.

I think you have hold the wrong end of the stick. It's because the
distinction is dead in most places, dying in some, that many people
don't know it's still alive anywhere.

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Sir, I quite agree with you, but what are we two against so many?
--George Bernard Shaw,
to a man booing at the opening of _Arms and the Man_
